original_title: Start or perish; Sri Lanka gives ultimatum for halted investments with state lands
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lankan government has given an ultimatum for investors who have secured valuable state lands for investments, but delayed the start of their projects.

Arundika Fernando, State Minister of Urban Development and Housing said President Ranil Wickremesinghe’s government has also decided to distribute properties with commercial worth in major cities, notably Colombo to new investors in a way that will strengthen the economy.

“So far, the government has given the opportunity to investors to start projects on commercially valuable land in Colombo. But due to the poor economic situation the country faced, these projects have been halted,” Fernando told a media briefing on Friday (21).

“Therefore, we have informed them in writing to restart the relevant projects. If the investors do not take a decision before the end of next month, those projects will be taken over by the government and given to new investors.”
Land availability is a key constraint facing foreign and domestic investors in Sri Lanka, more than other ‘ease of doing business’ problems, analysts have said.
Most of Sri Lanka’s land is owned by the government partly due to a British era waste land ordinance.

Freehold lands developed in Sri Lanka under Western rule but after independence the state expropriated large tracts of productive land from citizens, leaving only a small proportion of land in their hands, critics say.
Even now the state expropriates lands in the hands of the private sector, claiming they are under-utilized, violating property rights and scaring away investors, according to other analysts.

Before the island nation’s sovereign debt default in April last year, the previous government under former leader Gotabaya Rajapaksa was in the process of leasing lands for investments, but no investment projects started due to the country’s unprecedented bankruptcy.

With a gradual economic recovery backed by International Monetary Fund reforms, the government is inow n the process of fast tracking the investment which had already secured state lands on a long term lease.

“Currently, Hilton Hotel is a lucrative business. As a result, it has been agreed to safeguard employee rights as well as the Hilton hotel chain’s conventions and improve it in order to boost the country’s economy,” Fernando said.

“Along with this, steps are being taken to transfer ownership of the Battaramulla-based Waters Edge Hotel to new investors. Additionally, a committee has been established by President Ranil Wickremesinghe to examine how these new initiatives would be carried out.”
He also said 24 coastal regions have been designated as tourist destinations which have been decided to be given to investors to  boost the national economy. (Colombo/July 21/2023)
